title: How is the class-order in an Explainer object defined?
body:
Say I have the following 3-class classification problem:


```python

import xgboost
import shap
import numpy as np

X, y = make_classification(
    n_samples=1000, n_informative=10, n_redundant=10, n_classes=3, random_state=42)
X_t, X_v, y_t, y_v = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.1, random_state=42)


conditions = [y==0,y==1,y==2]
values = ["c","a","b"]
y = np.select(conditions,values)
```
since the "order" of `y` is now "messed up", when I think do 

```python
model_xgb = xgboost.XGBClassifier().fit(X, y)
tree_explainer_xgb = shap.TreeExplainer(model_xgb)
```

then `tree_explainer_xgb` is a 3-d array. How do I know which dimension is what i.e is `tree_explainer_xgb[:,:,0]` the "a","b" or "c" class? Is it the same order as in `model_xgb.classes_` (`["a","b","c"]`) e.g `tree_explainer_xgb[:,:,0]` is for class "a"? And what if the model does not have the `classes_` property?


I notice that for the RandomForestClassifier, when we have a 2-class problem we still have that the `shap.TreeExplainer(model_random_forest)` is 3-dimensional whereas for the same dataset, but using XGBoost it is 2-dimensional.

How do we know which models produces which dimension i.e if they in the binary case outputs a 3-dimensional or 2-dimensional?
